articles.headline: Stocks Decline as Price of Oil Rises Sharply
articles.snippet: The Dow Jones industrials fell below 12,000 as a host of options and futures contracts hit their expiration dates.
articles.abstract: The Dow Jones industrials fell below 12,000 as a host of options and futures contracts hit their expiration dates.
articles.lead_paragraph: A market that had been looking for direction in recent weeks seems to have found one: down.

articles.headline: Banks Trimming Limits for Many on Credit Cards
articles.snippet: After fostering the explosive growth of consumer debt in recent years, financial companies are reducing the credit limits on cards held by millions of Americans, often without warning.
articles.abstract: After fostering the explosive growth of consumer debt in recent years, financial companies are reducing the credit limits on cards held by millions of Americans, often without warning.
articles.lead_paragraph: The easy money that led Americans to depend on credit cards to pay their bills is starting to dry up.

articles.headline: 8 Reasons You Should Not Expect an Inheritance
articles.snippet: Costs are rising, retirement income is less secure and the golden years are lasting longer, leaving older people less to bequeath to their heirs.
articles.abstract: Costs are rising, retirement income is less secure and the golden years are lasting longer, leaving older people less to bequeath to their heirs.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard about the bumper sticker, even if you haven’t seen it. It’s the one on Cadillacs in Florida and Lexuses in Arizona that says “I’m spending my children’s inheritance.”

articles.headline: U.S. May Free Up More Land for Corn Crops
articles.snippet: Midwest floods have washed out millions of acres of corn, and many are urging Washington to allow corn to be grown on protected land and to roll back requirements for ethanol production.
articles.abstract: Midwest floods have washed out millions of acres of corn, and many are urging Washington to allow corn to be grown on protected land and to roll back requirements for ethanol production.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Signs are growing that the government may allow farmers to plant crops on millions of acres of conservation land, while a chorus of voices is also pleading with Washington to cut requirements for ethanol production.

articles.headline: Ready to Attack Obama, if Some Money Arrives
articles.snippet: One activist’s struggles could indicate that independent groups on the right may be less successful than in 2004.
articles.abstract: One activist’s struggles could indicate that independent groups on the right may be less successful than in 2004.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash.  A Bible verse taped to a whiteboard in Floyd Brown’s office that he uses to track his efforts to attack Senator Barack Obama reads, “That is why for Christ’s sake I delight in weakness, in insults, in hardships, in persecutions, in difficulties.”

articles.headline: Travelers Shift to Rail as Cost of Fuel Rises
articles.snippet: Amtrak has set records for its number of passengers and ticket revenues, but it faces many difficulties in growing quickly enough to meet demand.
articles.abstract: Amtrak has set records for its number of passengers and ticket revenues, but it faces many difficulties in growing quickly enough to meet demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Record prices for gasoline and jet fuel should be good news for Amtrak, as travelers look for alternatives to cut the cost of driving and flying.

articles.headline: Big Gains for Iraq Security, but Questions Linger
articles.snippet: Despite great strides in tamping down violence, Iraq lacks the formal rules to share power and spoils.
articles.abstract: Despite great strides in tamping down violence, Iraq lacks the formal rules to share power and spoils.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  What’s going right? And can it last?
articles.byline: By Stephen Farrell and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: A.M.D. and Its War With Intel
articles.snippet: Antitrust investigations are so maddening that the Federal Trade Commission is likely to have a hard time getting to the bottom of the case against Intel.
articles.abstract: Antitrust investigations are so maddening that the Federal Trade Commission is likely to have a hard time getting to the bottom of the case against Intel.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Stephen Labaton of The New York Times broke the news that the Federal Trade Commission had decided to open a formal antitrust investigation into Intel, the world’s dominant maker of microprocessors. Subpoenas had gone out not just to Intel, but to many of the computer manufacturers who rely on Intel chips. The investigation, as Mr. Labaton wrote, was going to revolve around “accusations that Intel’s pricing is intended to maintain a near monopoly on the microprocessor market.”

articles.headline: Why Is Oil So High? Pick a View
articles.snippet: What confounds many experts is that the price of oil seems to be changing much faster than the world is changing.
articles.abstract: What confounds many experts is that the price of oil seems to be changing much faster than the world is changing.
articles.lead_paragraph: People who have spent their careers tracking the ups and downs of the global oil markets say their compasses are spinning. Oil prices rise for reasons they cannot quite fathom, and where prices will be a year from now has become, literally, anybody’s guess.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: To the Trenches: The Tort War Is Raging On
articles.snippet: Corporate interests have won several victories, but trial lawyers continue to try to undo legislation restricting litigation and are pursuing new strategies of their own.
articles.abstract: Corporate interests have won several victories, but trial lawyers continue to try to undo legislation restricting litigation and are pursuing new strategies of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN a Washington ballroom bedecked with flags honoring explorers who overcame oceans and mountains to pursue international trade, Thomas J. Donohue congratulated the assembled modern merchants  a group of executives, lobbyists and lawyers  for challenging a more mundane adversary.

articles.headline: Assassins in Zimbabwe Aim at the Grass Roots
articles.snippet: At least 85 people have been killed in a campaign against the opposition in a presidential runoff, civic groups said.
articles.abstract: At least 85 people have been killed in a campaign against the opposition in a presidential runoff, civic groups said.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  Tonderai Ndira was a shrewd choice for assassination: young, courageous and admired. Kill him and fear would pulse through a thousand spines. He was an up-and-comer in Zimbabwe’s opposition party, a charismatic figure with a strong following in the Harare slums where he lived.
articles.byline: By Barry Bearak and Celia W. Dugger

articles.headline: Fighting a War Against Distraction
articles.snippet: Frequent topics of discussion these days include the interruptions of working in the digital age, the mistakes we make while multitasking and the efforts to find quiet places to think.
articles.abstract: Frequent topics of discussion these days include the interruptions of working in the digital age, the mistakes we make while multitasking and the efforts to find quiet places to think.
articles.lead_paragraph: The subject of focus comes up a lot in my discussions with people about work. We talk about the constant interruptions of working in the digital age, of the mistakes we make while multitasking and the efforts to find quiet places to think.

articles.headline: National Push by Obama on Ads and Turnout
articles.snippet: Barack Obama hopes to capitalize on a fund-raising lead to force Republicans to compete in states they usually win.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama hopes to capitalize on a fund-raising lead to force Republicans to compete in states they usually win.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama is drawing up plans for extensive advertising and voter-turnout drives across the nation, hoping to capitalize on his expected fund-raising advantage over Senator John McCain to force Republicans to compete in states they have not had to defend in decades.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: In Fertile India, Growth Outstrips Agriculture
articles.snippet: India’s supply of arable land is second only to that of the U.S., but it must buy some foods on international markets, exacerbating a global food crisis.
articles.abstract: India’s supply of arable land is second only to that of the U.S., but it must buy some foods on international markets, exacerbating a global food crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: JALANDHAR, India  With the right technology and policies, India could help feed the world. Instead, it can barely feed itself.

articles.headline: The New Trophy Home, Small and Ecological
articles.snippet: Homes are a new arena for LEED ratings, environmental badges of honor usually given to commercial buildings.
articles.abstract: Homes are a new arena for LEED ratings, environmental badges of honor usually given to commercial buildings.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the high-profile crowd that turned out to celebrate a new home in Venice, Calif., the attraction wasn’t just the company and the architectural detail. The house boasted the builders’ equivalent of a three-star Michelin rating: a LEED platinum certificate.

articles.headline: Call for Change Ignored, Levees Remain Patchy
articles.snippet: Few of a presidential panel’s recommendations after the Midwest’s devastating flood in 1993 were implemented.
articles.abstract: Few of a presidential panel’s recommendations after the Midwest’s devastating flood in 1993 were implemented.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANTON, Mo.  The levees along the Mississippi River offer a patchwork of unpredictable protections. Some are tall and earthen, others aging and sandy, and many along its tributaries uncataloged by federal officials.

articles.headline: Nothing Sells Like Celebrity
articles.snippet: Where stars end and products and pitches begin has grown less and less discernible in the era of the human billboard.
articles.abstract: Where stars end and products and pitches begin has grown less and less discernible in the era of the human billboard.
articles.lead_paragraph: EARLY last year, marketing executives at Totes Isotoner, a Cincinnati company that had spent the previous 30 years churning out a reliable lineup of humble umbrellas, crowded around a computer and listened to a teenage singer from Barbados named Rihanna breeze through a tune titled, appropriately, “Umbrella.”

articles.headline: How Big a Payday for the Pay Consultants?
articles.snippet: An approach to runaway executive pay might involve looking at potential conflicts of interest that compensation consultants may have as they provide other services to companies as well.
articles.abstract: An approach to runaway executive pay might involve looking at potential conflicts of interest that compensation consultants may have as they provide other services to companies as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE credit crisis, rising oil prices and the economy may dominate headlines, but excessive executive pay still makes shareholders boil. With the proxy season pretty much over  and with John McCain and Barack Obama both making compensation a campaign issue  let’s see where investors stand in the battle to rein in outsized pay.

articles.headline: Bill to Protect Companies in Inquiries Adds Support
articles.snippet: Ex-prosecutors praised a proposed rule on confidential legal contact that has come under attack amid corporate fraud scandals.
articles.abstract: Ex-prosecutors praised a proposed rule on confidential legal contact that has come under attack amid corporate fraud scandals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly three dozen former federal prosecutors have thrown their weight behind a Congressional bill intended to safeguard confidential communications between lawyers and their clients, a legal bedrock that has come under attack amid corporate fraud scandals.

articles.headline: Agreements Are Elusive at Oil Talks in Saudi Arabia
articles.snippet: The Saudis pledged to make only a slight increase in oil production, and the summit made plain how few options are available to push prices down from record levels.
articles.abstract: The Saudis pledged to make only a slight increase in oil production, and the summit made plain how few options are available to push prices down from record levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  A hastily convened global energy summit meeting led by Saudi Arabia ended largely in disagreement on Sunday, with only a modest pledge of increased production by the Saudis and no resolution on what other practical steps should be taken to ease the crisis over soaring oil prices.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Bollywood Goes to Hollywood, Seeking Bargains
articles.snippet: Reliance Entertainment, part of an Indian conglomerate, is in talks to finance Steven Spielberg and David Geffen in a new venture.
articles.abstract: Reliance Entertainment, part of an Indian conglomerate, is in talks to finance Steven Spielberg and David Geffen in a new venture.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  Hollywood loves to show outside investors just how the movie business really works. But some of the people behind Bollywood in India believe they have something to teach Hollywood about making movies.

articles.headline: Obama Camp Closely Linked With Ethanol
articles.snippet: The ethanol industry has provided some top advisers to Senator Barack Obama, who has delivered ringing endorsements of ethanol as an alternative fuel.
articles.abstract: The ethanol industry has provided some top advisers to Senator Barack Obama, who has delivered ringing endorsements of ethanol as an alternative fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: When VeraSun Energy inaugurated a new ethanol processing plant last summer in Charles City, Iowa, some of that industry’s most prominent boosters showed up. Leaders of the National Corn Growers Association and the Renewable Fuels Association, for instance, came to help cut the ribbon  and so did Senator Barack Obama.

articles.headline: New Outreach to Blacks as Border Patrol Grows
articles.snippet: Border Patrol officials acknowledge that black recruits have often been overlooked or been difficult to attract.
articles.abstract: Border Patrol officials acknowledge that black recruits have often been overlooked or been difficult to attract.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS  Nearly 1,500 miles from his post at the Mexican border, Cyril V. Atherton, a Border Patrol agent, embarked on one of his trickiest missions.

articles.headline: Live Music Thrives as CDs Fade
articles.snippet: Yes, the traditional music industry is in the tank, but for some niche bands that’s not such a bad thing.
articles.abstract: Yes, the traditional music industry is in the tank, but for some niche bands that’s not such a bad thing.
articles.lead_paragraph: A little over a week ago, Patterson Hood, a guitarist and singer in the Drive-By Truckers, stood in front of a sleepy but amped noon crowd at Bonnaroo, the music festival in Manchester, Tenn., explaining profanely that it was time to, um, wake up. As he kicked into “The Righteous Path,” a song from the group’s new-ish record “Brighter Than Creation’s Dark,” it was if the space in front of him was filled with sunburned bobble-heads, each bouncing in unison to every word: “Trying to hold steady on the righteous path, 80 miles an hour with a worn-out map.”

articles.headline: The New Fight for Financial News
articles.snippet: Thomson Reuters is going hard after Bloomberg L.P., which has long been the marquee name on Wall Street for financial information.
articles.abstract: Thomson Reuters is going hard after Bloomberg L.P., which has long been the marquee name on Wall Street for financial information.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO  For years, the Thomson Corporation was the information giant that rarely talked about its own business.

articles.headline: An Unlikely Promoter Drives Nokia’s Push in Hollywood
articles.snippet: While once formidable competitors like Motorola struggle to deliver their phones on time, Nokia wants to transform itself into a next-generation entertainment company.
articles.abstract: While once formidable competitors like Motorola struggle to deliver their phones on time, Nokia wants to transform itself into a next-generation entertainment company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.  Tero Ojanpera is an unlikely media entrepreneur. Mr. Ojanpera, a veteran Nokia executive, is not a fan of “American Idol,” although he says he enjoys it from time to time. And when he tried to watch a recent episode of “Hannah Montana,” one of his sons switched the channel.

articles.headline: Mugabe Rival Quits Zimbabwe Runoff, Citing Attacks
articles.snippet: Saying he could not ask his voters to risk their lives, Morgan Tsvangirai pulled out of the race, a move that seemed intended to force action from other nations.
articles.abstract: Saying he could not ask his voters to risk their lives, Morgan Tsvangirai pulled out of the race, a move that seemed intended to force action from other nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  The leader of Zimbabwe’s opposition party withdrew Sunday from a presidential runoff, just five days before it was to be held, saying he could neither participate “in this violent, illegitimate sham of an election process,” nor ask his voters to risk their lives in the face of threats from forces backing President Robert Mugabe.
articles.byline: By Celia W. Dugger and Barry Bearak

articles.headline: In Algeria, a Tug of War for Young Minds
articles.snippet: The ideological battle for Algeria’s youth takes place in the schools, which for decades were controlled by Islamists.
articles.abstract: The ideological battle for Algeria’s youth takes place in the schools, which for decades were controlled by Islamists.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALGIERS  First, Abdel Malek Outas’s teachers taught him to write math equations in Arabic, and embrace Islam and the Arab world. Then they told him to write in Latin letters that are no longer branded unpatriotic, and open his mind to the West.
